definitions: perceive or detect something using the sense of smell
apply a pleasant smell or fragrance to something
examples: The dog scented the rabbit hiding in the bushes
She could scent freshly baked bread from the kitchen
They scented the laundry with lavender essential oil
The company scents their stores to create a welcoming atmosphere

definitions: cut something using scissors or perform a cutting motion
move legs in a crossing motion like scissor blades opening and closing
examples: She carefully scissored the fabric along the pattern lines
The hairdresser scissored through his thick hair expertly
The swimmer scissored her legs to stay afloat
The gymnast scissored his legs during the floor routine

definitions: speak to someone angrily because they have done something wrong or behaved badly
examples: The teacher scolded the students for not doing their homework
His mother scolded him for coming home late without calling

definitions: pick up or move something with a scoop or similar implement
obtain and publish news or information before competitors or rivals
examples: She scooped ice cream into bowls for the children
He scooped the fallen leaves into a garbage bag
The journalist scooped all other newspapers with the breaking story
They managed to scoop their competitors on the merger announcement

definitions: go or move somewhere quickly often in a casual or playful manner
examples: The children scooted off to play in the backyard
She had to scoot to catch the last train home

definitions: burn the surface of something with flame or heat causing discoloration or damage
examples: The iron was too hot and scorched her favorite blouse
The summer sun scorched the grass until it turned brown

definitions: feel or express contempt or derision for someone or something considered unworthy
examples: She scorned his attempts to apologize for his behavior
The critics scorned the movie as predictable and poorly acted

definitions: decisively put an end to something or prevent it from happening
examples: The company quickly scotched rumors about massive layoffs
They scotched the plan when they realized it was too expensive

definitions: clean or brighten something by rubbing it hard with rough material
search a place or area thoroughly and carefully for something
examples: She scoured the pot until it shone like new
He scoured the bathtub with a strong cleaning solution
Police scoured the neighborhood looking for the missing child
We scoured the internet for the best travel deals

definitions: cause great suffering or severe trouble to a person group or place
examples: The plague scourged Europe during the Middle Ages
Poverty continues to scourge many developing nations around the world

definitions: scratch or grope around with fingers or claws to find or hold something
examples: The cat scrabbled at the door wanting to come inside
She scrabbled in her purse looking for her car keys

definitions: climb or move quickly using hands and feet especially over rough ground
mix things together in a confused or disordered way
struggle or compete eagerly with others for something
examples: The hikers scrambled up the rocky mountain trail
Children scrambled over the playground equipment during recess
She scrambled the letters to create a word puzzle
The storm scrambled all the papers on his desk
Shoppers scrambled for the best deals on Black Friday
Companies scrambled to hire the top graduates

definitions: discard or remove something because it is no longer useful or wanted
have a brief fight or quarrel typically informal or spontaneous
examples: They decided to scrap the old car for parts
The company scrapped its plans for expansion
The two boys scrapped in the schoolyard over a toy
Siblings often scrap over minor things but make up quickly

definitions: drag or pull a hard or sharp implement across a surface to remove something
barely manage to achieve or succeed in something with difficulty
examples: She scraped the old paint off the window frame
He scraped ice from the car windshield every winter morning
They scraped together enough money for the rent
She barely scraped through her final exams

definitions: make a loud harsh piercing cry or sound like that of brakes or tires
examples: The car's brakes screeched as it came to a sudden stop
The owl screeched in the darkness of the night

definitions: take a digital image capture of what is displayed on a computer or device screen
examples: She screenshot the error message to show tech support
Students screenshot important slides during the online lecture

definitions: write down or record information especially in an official or formal capacity
examples: The secretary scribed the minutes of the important meeting
Ancient monks scribed religious texts by hand in monasteries

definitions: engage in a practice game or informal match especially in team sports
examples: The football team scrimmaged against each other before the season
The coach had them scrimmage to test new plays

definitions: move text or images up or down on a computer screen
unroll or spread out a rolled document or parchment
examples: She scrolled through social media posts on her phone
He scrolled down to find the information he needed
The scholar carefully scrolled the ancient manuscript
They scrolled the diploma before presenting it

definitions: clean something by rubbing it hard with a brush and water
cancel or abandon a plan or scheduled event especially at the last minute
examples: She scrubbed the floor until it was spotlessly clean
The nurse scrubbed her hands before entering the operating room
NASA scrubbed the launch due to bad weather conditions
They scrubbed their vacation plans when he got sick

definitions: move fast in a straight line driven by wind or as if driven by wind
examples: Dark clouds scudded across the stormy sky
The small boat scudded before the strong wind

definitions: engage in a short confused fight or struggle at close quarters
examples: The security guards scuffled with protesters outside the building
The two players scuffled on the field before being separated

definitions: propel a boat with oars especially using a rowing technique with oars at the stern
examples: She sculled her small boat across the peaceful lake
The rower sculled smoothly through the morning mist

definitions: create a three-dimensional artwork by carving or shaping materials like stone clay or wood
examples: The artist sculpted a beautiful statue from marble
She learned to sculpt figures from clay in art class

definitions: form a layer of dirt or foam on top of a liquid
examples: Algae scummed the surface of the neglected swimming pool
The soup scummed over as it cooled on the stove

definitions: move hurriedly with short quick steps often in a busy or nervous way
examples: Mice scurried across the attic floor at night
Office workers scurried to catch the last elevator

definitions: run hurriedly or furtively with short quick steps
deliberately cause a ship to sink by making holes in the bottom
examples: The crab scuttled sideways across the sandy beach
She scuttled away when she saw her ex-boyfriend approaching
The captain scuttled his ship rather than let enemies capture it
They scuttled the old vessel to create an artificial reef

definitions: cut crops or grass with a scythe tool that has a long curved blade
examples: The farmer scythed the wheat field before the storm arrived
He scythed the tall grass around the old barn

definitions: join two pieces of fabric or material together by sewing along the edge
examples: She carefully seamed the dress panels together
The tailor seamed the jacket sleeves with precision

definitions: pilot or travel in an aircraft designed to take off and land on water
examples: The pilot seaplaned tourists to remote island destinations
They seaplaned across the lake to reach the fishing lodge

definitions: burn or scorch the surface of something with sudden intense heat
examples: The chef seared the steak to lock in the juices
The hot iron seared a mark into the wooden table

definitions: withdraw formally from membership in a political union alliance or organization
examples: Several states threatened to secede from the union
The province voted to secede from the country

definitions: produce and discharge a substance from cells or glands in the body
hide something in a secret place to conceal it from others
examples: The glands secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream
Some plants secrete nectar to attract pollinating insects
The spy secreted the documents in a hidden compartment
She secreted her diary under the loose floorboard

definitions: administer a drug to someone to calm them or make them sleep
examples: The veterinarian sedated the injured dog before treatment
Doctors sedated the patient before the major surgery

definitions: settle to the bottom of a liquid as particles or matter
examples: Sand and silt sediment at the bottom of the river
The wine needs time to sediment before decanting

definitions: persuade someone to do something or behave in a certain way by making it seem attractive
examples: The company tried to seduce customers with special offers
He was seduced by the promise of easy money

definitions: flow or leak slowly through small openings or porous material
examples: Water seeped through the cracks in the basement wall
The smell of coffee seeped into the hallway

definitions: move up and down or back and forth in an alternating pattern
examples: Stock prices seesawed throughout the trading day
The children seesawed in the playground for hours

definitions: separate people or things into different groups based on race class or other characteristics
examples: The prison segregates violent offenders from other inmates
Some schools used to segregate students by academic ability

definitions: move smoothly and without interruption from one piece of music activity or topic to another
examples: The speaker segued from economics into environmental policy
The band segued perfectly from one song to the next

definitions: catch fish using a large fishing net that hangs vertically in the water
examples: Local fishermen seine for salmon during the spawning season
They seined the shallow waters near the shore

definitions: send messages or signals using a system of holding flags in different positions
examples: The sailor semaphored a message to the nearby ship
Boy scouts learned to semaphore during their camping trip

definitions: isolate or hide away someone or something from outside contact or influence
examples: The jury was sequestered during the high-profile trial
She sequestered herself in her room to finish the project

definitions: sing to someone especially a romantic song typically outdoors at night
examples: He serenaded his girlfriend outside her bedroom window
The mariachi band serenaded diners at the restaurant

definitions: provide something with a row of sharp points along the edge like a saw
examples: The manufacturer serrated the knife blade for cutting bread
Nature serrated the leaves to help with water drainage

definitions: cut off something completely or divide by cutting through it forcefully
examples: The accident severed the cable causing a power outage
She decided to sever all ties with her former business partner

definitions: join attach or repair something by making stitches with a needle and thread
examples: She learned to sew buttons on her shirts
My grandmother could sew beautiful quilts by hand

definitions: live in or stay at a place temporarily often in poor conditions
examples: They shacked in an old cabin during the fishing trip
Students often shack together to save money on rent

definitions: chain or fasten someone with shackles to restrict their movement or freedom
examples: Guards shackled the prisoner before transporting him to court
Debt can shackle people for years

definitions: treat someone harshly or unfairly especially by cheating or taking advantage of them
examples: The company shafted its workers by cutting their benefits
He felt his business partner had shafted him in the deal
